sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: Dir.Current returns the full path name of the current execution directory. This is the equivalent of doing a pwd in UNIX.
sections.text_content: Dir.Current returns the full path name of the current execution directory. This is the equivalent of doing a pwd in UNIX.
sections.mdown_content: **Dir.Current** returns the full path name of the current execution directory. This is the equivalent of doing a **pwd** in UNIX.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: If the Dir.Current call fails, then Error.Last will return a non-zero value indicating the reason for the failure. Error.LastMsg will return a string which contains the textual version of the error.
sections.text_content: If the Dir.Current call fails, then Error.Last will return a non-zero value indicating the reason for the failure. Error.LastMsg will return a string which contains the textual version of the error.
sections.mdown_content: If the **Dir.Current** call fails, then **Error.Last** will return a non-zero value indicating the reason for the failure. **Error.LastMsg** will return a string which contains the textual version of the error.

sections.title: Example
code:
Dir.Change ("/usr/west")
        if Error.Last = eNoError  then
            put "Directory changed"
        else
            put "Did not change the directory."
            put "Error: ", Error.LastMsg
        end if
        put "The current execution directory is ", Dir.Current
sections.raw_content: This program changes to the directory called /usr/west and then lists the current directory.
sections.text_content: This program changes to the directory called /usr/west and then lists the current directory.
sections.mdown_content: This program changes to the directory called _/usr/west_ and then lists the current directory.

sections.title: Example
sections.raw_content:
An example demonstrating the use of several of the Dir subprograms is available. In this example, a directory is created, a file is written to the directory, an attempt is made to delete the directory, the file is deleted, and then the directory is deleted.

This example demonstrates the use of Dir.Change, Dir.Current, Dir.Create, and Dir.Delete.
sections.text_content:
An example demonstrating the use of several of the Dir subprograms
      is available. In this example, a directory is created, a file is written
      to the directory, an attempt is made to delete the directory, the file is
      deleted, and then the directory is deleted.
      This example demonstrates the use of Dir.Change, 
      Dir.Current, Dir.Create, and Dir.Delete.
sections.mdown_content:
An example demonstrating the use of several of the **Dir** subprogramsis available. In this example, a directory is created, a file is writtento the directory, an attempt is made to delete the directory, the file isdeleted, and then the directory is deleted.
This example demonstrates the use of **Dir.Change**, **Dir.Current**, **Dir.Create**, and **Dir.Delete**.

sections.title: Status
sections.raw_content:
Exported qualified.

This means that you can only call the function by calling Dir.Current, not by calling Current.
sections.text_content:
Exported qualified.
This means that you can only call the function by calling Dir.Current, not by calling Current.
sections.mdown_content:
Exported qualified.
This means that you can only call the function by calling **Dir.Current**, not by calling **Current**.
